title: How to improve your framing and composition in street photography - Quora

response.answer_text: There is a cult that permeates most photographic domains. That cult claims, vociferously and often, that cropping is some sort of capital offence, some intolerable aberration that distinguishes amateurs from ‘better photographers’ or those ‘not in the know.’ Respectfully, the notion is complete garbage. Composition is a complex skill. Some have it, naturally. Others learn the principles with experience and experimentation. Whatever the attributes, innate or learned, the end result is the same. Here are a couple of shots I edited today… Man on a Mission.Kauno senamiestis: Kaunas Old Town.Lietuva-Lithuania.Fujifilm XF10  The final result us about thirty percent of the original RAW file. The shot was taken quickly - 1/350 - as I followed the group up the subway steps. I was attracted by the somewhat macho male with a bunch of red roses. When curating the originals, I ‘saw’ what I have in this version. Photography is all about ‘seeing’. The Sky’s the Limit.Kaunas City.Lietuva-Lithuania.Ricoh GR  Here, I wanted the interplay between the reflection on the large glass building facade and the foreground space. I was attracted by the way the glass distorted the clouds and attempted to show that with filtration in Photoshop. Again, this is about thirty percent of the original file. There are many learned theses by photographers about composition principles. Ignore most of those, particularly the constipating ‘Rule of Thirds’ and look, instead, at the work these theoreticians and critical thinkers produce. That is the proof of the ‘Composition Pudding’, what photographers can do rather than what they say.

Use your entire format, try not to crop. Shot a lot and give enough time to edition. Learn from your mistakes. Focusing and reading exposures takes a lot of time, pre focus and calculate exposure in advance, just raise your camera to snap. There is a book on composition by Kandinsky, “ Punto y linea sobre el plano” was the name in spanish, it teach you a lot on composition.
